Long name: Maximum rate of photosynthesis in saturated light per leaf area.
Long definition: Maximum rate photosynthesis is determined by the slower of two biochemical rates: the carboxylation of RuBP, determined by Rubisco activity (VCMAX); and electron transport for RuBP regeneration in the Calvin cycle (JMAXQ). When only light is saturating, the maximum rate of photosynthesis will be determined by the carboxylation of RuBP (Farquhar et al., 1980). Photosynthesis measured by IRGAs (Infrared Gas Analyzer system) is obtained in an area base. Photosynthesis in a mass base can be normalized to area base by simply dividing AMASS to leaf mass area (LMAQQ). Area based traits reflect surface fluxes such as light harvesting and transactions through surfaces such as carbon assimilation and water transpiration (Wright et al., 2004).
Label: maximum, photosynthesis, saturated light, leaf area

Long name: Maximum rate of photosynthesis in saturated light and CO2 per leaf area
Long definition: Maximum rate photosynthesis is determined by the slower of two biochemical rates: the carboxylation of RuBP, determined by Rubisco activity (VCMAX); and electron transport for RuBP regeneration in the Calvin cycle (JMAXQ) (Farquhar et al., 1980). Photosynthesis measured by IRGAs (Infrared Gas Analyzer system) is obtained in an area base. Photosynthesis in a mass base can be normalized to area base by simply dividing AMASS to leaf mass area (LMAQQ). Area based traits reflect surface fluxes such as light harvesting and transactions through surfaces such as carbon assimilation and water transpiration (Wright et al., 2004).
Label: maximum, photosynthesis, saturated light, leaf area, CO2

Long name: Maximum rate of carboxylation per leaf area
Long definition: Maximum rate photosynthesis is determined by the slower of two biochemical rates: the carboxylation of RuBP, determined by Rubisco activity (VCMAX); and electron transport for RuBP regeneration in the Calvin cycle (JMAXQ). When light is saturating, the amount of activated Rubisco determines the maximum velocity of carboxylation, VCMAX (Farquhar et al., 1980). VCMAX in an area based is calculated from photosynthesis in an area base. Area based traits reflect surface fluxes such as light harvesting and transactions through surfaces such as carbon assimilation and water transpiration (Wright et al., 2004).
Label: maximum, leaf area, carboxylation

Long name: Maximum rate of electron transport per leaf area
Long definition: Maximum rate photosynthesis is determined by the slower of two biochemical rates: the carboxylation of RuBP, determined by Rubisco activity (VCMAX); and electron transport for RuBP regeneration in the Calvin cycle (JMAXQ). When intercellular CO2 is saturating, the carboxylation capacity is determined by the maximum rate of electron transport, JMAXQ (Farquhar et al., 1980). JMAXQ in an area based is calculated from photosynthesis in an area base. Area based traits reflect surface fluxes such as light harvesting and transactions through surfaces such as carbon assimilation and water transpiration (Wright et al., 2004).
Label: maximum, electron transport, leaf area

Long name: Rate of dark respiration per leaf area.
Long definition: Between a quarter and a half of the carbon fixed by plants is released back as CO2 to the atmosphere by leaf respiration on a daily basis. Leaf mitochondrial respiration in the absence of light (Rdark) is a major component of total leaf respiration (Farquhar et al., 1980, Poorter et al., 1990). RDARK in a mass based is calculated from RDARK in an area base. Area based traits reflect surface fluxes such as light harvesting and transactions through surfaces such as carbon assimilation and water transpiration (Wright et al., 2004).
Label: dark respiration, leaf area

Long name: Maximum rate of photosynthesis in saturated light per leaf area at an ambient temperature of 25 degrees Celsius.
Long definition: Maximum rate photosynthesis is determined by the slower of two biochemical rates: the carboxylation of RuBP, determined by Rubisco activity (Vcmax); and electron transport for RuBP regeneration in the Calvin cycle (Jmax). When light is saturating, the maximum rate of photosynthesis will be determined by the carboxylation of RuBP (Farquhar et al., 1980). Photosynthesis determined in ambient temperature is standardized to 25 degrees Celsius applying an adapted Arrenius equation (Bernacchi et al., 2009). This standardization reduces biases due to temperature effects. Photosynthesis measured by IRGAs (Infrared Gas Analyzer system) is obtained in an area base. Photosynthesis in a mass base can be normalized to area base by simply dividing AMASS to leaf mass area (LMAQQ). Area based traits reflect surface fluxes such as light harvesting and transactions through surfaces such as carbon assimilation and water transpiration (Wright et al., 2004).
Label: maximum, photosynthesis, saturated light, leaf area, temperature

Long name: Intercellular to ambient CO2 mole fraction.
Long definition: Carbon assimilation rate depends on the CO2 leaf intercellular concentration and the diffusion of atmospheric CO2 into the leaf is mainly regulated by stomatal conductance (Farquhar et al., 1980). Simultaneously, stomatal conductance also permits leaves to transpire. The ratio CICAQ is a parameter to reflect plant strategy to regulate water losses through transpiration and carbon assimilation by photosynthesis (Prentice et al., 2014).
Label: intercellular, CO2, mole fraction

Long definition: By convention, stem diameter of trees is usually measured at 130 cm above ground (Cornelissen et al., 2003).
Label: diameter, breast height

Long definition: The main carboxylating enzyme, ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase (Rubisco) discriminates against 13C because of the intrinsically lower reactivity of 13C. As carboxylation and leaf CO2 diffusion are integrated, _C13 can be used as a proxy for the ratio of intercellular and atmospheric partial pressures of CO2 (Farquhar et al., 1982).
Label: carbon isotope

Long name: Leaf transpiration per leaf area under saturated light.
Long definition: Transpiration is the loss of water through stomata. The evaporation of water from the leaves results from the water movement along an individual plant and the force driving it is a chain of differences in water potential from roots, stems and branches, leaves and atmosphere. ETRAN is associated to leaf VPD and both are outputs from leaf gas measurements (Eamus, 2006).
Label: transpiration, leaf area, saturated light

Long name: Stomatal conductance per leaf area under saturated light.
Long definition: Stomata aperture in leaves is the main process to regulate diffusion of partial pressure of CO2 at the sites of carboxylation and the rate of transpiration. Stomatal conductance is correlated to carbon assimilation by photosynthesis and it is affected by solar radiation, temperature and climatic moisture (Medlyn et al., 2011).
Label: stomatal conductance, leaf area, saturated light

Long definition: HTMAX is the potential minimum vertical distance between the plant base at ground level and the upper boundary of photosynthetic tissues (Niklas, 2007). HTMAX is associated with successful competition for light, LAI, potential life span, photosynthesis per unit leaf area, biomass in leaves and trades-off in hydraulic conductance (Falster and Westoby, 2003).
Label: maximum, height

Long definition: Huber value _ the fraction of leaf area to cross-sectional sapwood area. Sapwood cross-sectional area of a stem or branch at any point should scale isometrically with the area of leaves distal to that point. This isometric relationship reflects plant strategies in assimilation revenue and wood supporting costs suggesting links between photosynthesis and transpiration (Tyree and Ewers, 1991).
Label: value

Long name: Maximum rate of electron transport per leaf area at an ambient temperature of 25 degrees Celsius.
Long definition: Maximum rate photosynthesis is determined by the slower of two biochemical rates: the carboxylation of RuBP, determined by Rubisco activity (Vcmax); and electron transport for RuBP regeneration in the Calvin cycle (Jmax). When intercellular CO2 is saturating, the carboxylation capacity is determined by the maximum rate of electron transport, Jmax RuBP (Farquhar et al., 1980). Jmax estimated in ambient temperature is standardized to 25 degrees Celsius applying an adapted Arrenius equation (Bernacchi et al., 2009). This standardization reduces biases due to temperature effects. Jmax in an area based is calculated from photosynthesis in an area base. Area based traits reflect surface fluxes such as light harvesting and transactions through surfaces such as carbon assimilation and water transpiration (Wright et al., 2004).
Label: maximum, electron transport, leaf area, temperature

Long definition: LAI is defined as the one-sided green leaf area per unit ground area and it can be determined by destructive and non-destructive methods. Non-destructive methods to estimate LAI include hemispherical (LAIPH) and aerial photography and satellite images (LAIST) (Macfarlane et al., 2007). LAI can be relative to one individual or specie or to a whole stand. It is a parameter widely used in different models from intercepting water to estimating gross primary production.
Label: leaf area, index

Long definition: LAI is defined as the one-sided green leaf area per unit ground area and it can be determined by destructive and non-destructive methods. Non-destructive methods to estimate LAI include hemispherical (LAIPH) and aerial photography and satellite images (LAIST) (Macfarlane et al., 2007). LAI can be relative to one individual or specie or to a whole stand. It is a parameter widely used in different models from intercepting water to estimating gross primary production.
Label: leaf area, index

Long definition: LAREA is used to obtain leaf mass per area (LMAQQ) or its inverse specific leaf area (SLA). Leaf area combined to other leaf morphologic traits such as thickness, mass, physical strength, phenology and life span is used to investigate carbon and water uses strategies in plants. Most studies harvest young fully expanded and hardened leaves and they should be scanned or measured in the same day of collection. One strategy to conserve the original area is to keep them in dark and moist (Cornelissen et al., 2003) .
Label: leaf area

Long definition: Plants life form is a classification that takes in account plantÍs structural architecture (e.g. tree, shrub, herb, grass, fern, forb, etc). Same species can present different life form as a way to adapt to different environments.
Label: plant, life form

Long definition: LMASS is used to obtain is used to obtain leaf mass per area (LMAQQ) or its inverse specific leaf area (SLA). LMASS combined to other leaf morphologic traits such as area, thickness, physical strength, phenology and life span is used to investigate carbon and water uses strategies in plants. Dry mass is obtained by desiccating the leaf in the oven at 60oC for at least 72h (or else at 80oC for 48h) (Cornelissen et al., 2003).
Label: leaf, dry mass

Long definition: Leaf Mass per Area (LMAQQ) is obtained by dividing Leaf Area (LAREA) by Dry Mass Content (LMASS) .Its inverse is called Specific Leaf Area (SLA). LMA is a key parameter in trade-offs between plant traits for its high correlation with photosynthetic processes. Combined to other leaf morphologic traits such as thickness, mass, physical strength, phenology and life span is used to investigate carbon and water uses strategies in plants (Wright et al., 2005). Most studies harvest young fully expanded and hardened leaves and they should be weighted, scanned or measured in the same day of collection. One strategy to conserve the original area is to keep them in dark and moist. Dry mass is obtained by desiccating the leaf in the oven at 60oC for at least 72h (or else at 80oC for 48h) (Cornelissen et al., 2003).
Label: leaf, dry mass, area

Long definition: LWDIT combined to other leaf morphologic traits such as area, thickness, physical strength, phenology and life span is used to investigate carbon and water uses strategies in plants. Most studies harvest young fully expanded and hardened leaves and they should be scanned or measured in the same day of collection. One strategy to conserve the original area is to keep them in dark and moist (Cornelissen et al., 2003).
Label: leaf, width

Long definition: Water potential quantifies the energy available to move water from one area to other by gravity, osmosis or other free energy. Water moves from areas of high to low water potential. During the day, the concentration of water vapour inside the sub-stomatal cavity is much larger than that in the atmosphere and water vapour diffuses (transpiration). Midday is an approximation that reflects the higher leaf water potential gradient in a day (Eamus, 2006).
Label: leaf, water potential

Long name: Nitrogen content per leaf dry mass.
Long definition: Nitrogen is a key nutrient for carbon fixation in plants. Most leaf nitrogen is found in the protein Rubisco that drives the photosynthetic process. N is usually measured in concentration but it can be transformed from an area base to mass base by simply dividing NAREA to leaf mass area (LMAQQ). Mass based traits reflect plant revenues and expenditures per unit investment (Wright et al., 2003, Wright et al., 2004).
Label: nitrogen, leaf, dry mass

Long name: Pre-dawn leaf water potential that is equivalent to soil water potential.
Long definition: Water potential quantifies the energy available to move water from one area to other by gravity, osmosis or other free energy. Water moves from areas of high to low water potential. During the day, the concentration of water vapour inside the sub-stomatal cavity is much larger than that in the atmosphere and water vapour diffuses (transpiration). Overnight, the sub-stomatal cavity equilibrates with the atmosphere (relative humidity at least 99.8%). As the soil profile dries out, pre-dawn water potential will decline in parallel (Eamus, 2006).
Label: pre-dawn, leaf, water potential, soil water potential

Long definition: The ratio of total photosynthesis to absorbed PAR by the leaf. PLLUE is used in studies in the framework of plant economic budgets for carbon and radiation. The term ñefficiencyî suggests plants tend to maximize carbon gain towards an optimum assimilation-costs budget. High PLLUE expresses efficient light sequestration and investment; low PLLUE indicates that less light is converted to biomass. Plant use efficiency for carbon, light, nitrogen and water are parameters combined to access plants inputs in biomass production process (Haxeltine and Prentice, 1996).
Label: light-use efficiency

Long name: Phosphorous content per leaf dry mass.
Long definition: Photosynthetic gain per unit leaf nitrogen is expected to be low in species inhabiting low-P soil sites. Leaf P, roots P and soil P are broadly correlated. As a result, the ratio N:P is frequently used in traits studies. P is usually measured in concentration but it can be transformed from an area base to mass base by simply dividing PAREA to leaf mass area (LMA). Mass based traits reflect plant revenues and expenditures per unit investment (Wright et al., 2003, Wright et al., 2004, Reich, 2014).
Label: phosphorous, leaf, dry mass

Long name: Biochemistry of the plant - photosyntheic pathway (e.g. C3, C3, CAM).
Long definition: Carbon is fixed in most plants by a biochemical process denominated C3 photosynthetic pathway. CO2 has to diffuse from the intercellular spaces to sites of carboxylation in the chloroplast and the fixation product in the calvin cycle is the 3-carbon compound 3-phosphoglycerate. In C4 species the CO2 fixation in the mesophyll cells is the 4-carbon compound oxaloacetate. This carbon is transported to the bundle-sheath cells via malate or aspartate and carbohydrates can be generated by the C3 pathway. C4 plants tend to have competitive advantage over C3 plants when light is abundant and temperatures high. However, C4 energy (ATP) requirements to ñpumpîCO2 are costly. In the Crassulacean acid metabolism (CAM), plants close stomata during the day to reduce transpiration and open at night to diffuse CO2. CAM calvin cycle site is in the chloroplast. CAM photosynthesis is advantageous in arid and very dry habitats. In C4 and CAM plants photorespiration is reduced, as Rubisco is more efficient in carbon fixation when competing with oxygen fixation (Atwell et al., 1999, von Caemmerer and Furbank, 2003).
Label: photosynthesis, pathway, c3, c4, cam

Long definition: Carbon assimilation is influenced by incident irradiance and CO2 leaf partial pressure. The quantum yield refers to the efficiency of photosynthetic utilization of light energy carried by a proton.  Here is defined as the initial slope of the relationship between carbon assimilation rate and irradiance in a given CO2 leaf partial pressure (Farquhar et al., 1980).
Label: leaf, quantum yield

Long name: Rate of dark respiration per leaf area at an ambient temperature of 25 degrees Celsius.
Long definition: Between a quarter and a half of the carbon fixed by plants is released back as CO2 to the atmosphere by leaf respiration on a daily basis. Leaf mitochondrial respiration in the absence of light (Rdark) is a major component of total leaf respiration (Farquhar et al., 1980, Poorter et al., 1990). Rdark estimated in ambient temperature is standardized to 25 degrees Celsius applying an adapted Arrenius equation (Bernacchi et al., 2009). This standardization reduces biases due to temperature effects. Vcmax in an area based is calculated from photosynthesis in an area base. Area based traits reflect surface fluxes such as light harvesting and transactions through surfaces such as carbon assimilation and water transpiration (Wright et al., 2004).
Label: dark respiration, leaf area, temperature

Long name: Total root biomass per ground area.
Long definition: Root biomass together with litterfall is the most important input of organic carbon to the soil. Belowground carbon mass and net primary production is more than twice aboveground. Investment in large roots follows the investment in fine root. Large roots are the biggest structural investment in most plants. Fine roots are associated to uptake of water and essential nutrients (Jackson et al., 1996).
Label: root, biomass, ground area

Long definition: Fine root radius is associated to uptake of water and essential nutrients. Individual plants can rapidly adjust their fine root system to compete in zones where limiting nutrients are made available. Fine roots are a more accurate indicator of root function than large roots. Carbon allocation increases to fine root radius when water and nutrients are a limiting factor to plant growth (Pregitzer et al., 2002).
Label: root, radius

Long definition: Plants with deep roots are expected to be well adapted to droughts and arid conditions. Deep roots are more frequently associated with plant water uptake but they can also affect the above ground carbon partitioning (investments in structural or photosynthetic tissues) and nutrient uptake (Canadell et al., 1996, Wang and Smith, 2004).
Label: root, depth

Long name: Plant hydraulic resistance to the transport of water.
Long definition: Plant hydraulic resistance is associated to leaf; stem and roots water potential. There is a time lag between water uptake by roots and transpiration from roots to leaves because of the resistance of the water flow. There is resistance to water movement by gravity, around soil particles, within membranes and cell walls in roots, inside the xylem by the frictional drag of cell walls and within the leaves because of membranes and cell walls. Hydraulic resistance is also associated to hydraulic architecture and plant height (Eamus, 2006).
Label: hydraulic resistance, water transport

Long name: Plant root resistance to the transport of water.
Long definition: Root resistance is associated to plant water potential. About half hydraulic resistance to movement of water is belowground. Soil resistance tends not to be large in moist soils and resistance to water flow occurs principally in the root. However, as the soil dries, its hydraulic conductance (the opposite of resistance) reduces and resistance in all parts of the plant will increase reducing transpiration and ultimately carbon assimilation (Eamus, 2006).
Label: root, resistance, water transport

Long name: Soils resistance in close proximity to roots.
Long definition: Soil resistance is associated to plant water potential. About half hydraulic resistance to movement of water is belowground. Soil resistance tends not to be large in moist soils and resistance to water flow occurs principally in the root. However, as the soil dries, its hydraulic conductance (the opposite of resistance) reduces and resistance in all parts of the plant will increase reducing transpiration and ultimately carbon assimilation (Eamus, 2006).
Label: soil, resistance, root

Long definition: Cross-sectional sapwood (or xylem) area is used as a proxy of plantÍs stem or branch water conducting tissue although the conducting parts are mostly vessels in angiosperms and traqueids in gimnosperms. When measured, the stem or branch total area is subtracted from bark and pith or heartwood. Cross-sectional sapwood area is expected to scale isometrically with the supplied leaf area in any part of the plant (pipe model theory) (Tyree and Ewers, 1991).
Label: sapwood, area

Long definition: Soil is one of the biggest sinks of carbon playing a key role in the carbon cycle. Organic carbon in soil is build-up from inputs of new plant and animal material and outputs of constant losses in decomposition separating mineral nutrients and gases. Organic matter is associated to soil fertility (http://www.csiro.au/Outcomes/Environment/Australian-Landscapes/soil-carbon.aspx).
Label: soil, nutrient, percentage, carbon

Long definition: Soil nitrogen is associated to photosynthesis. Nitrogen is a key nutrient for carbon fixation in plants and it is found in the protein Rubisco that drives the photosynthetic process (Evans, 1989). N inputs to the soil are mineral fertilization, wet and dry deposition, biological fixation and sedimentation. N outputs to the soil are aboveground plant N, leaching, denitrification and erosion (Vitousek et al., 1997).
Label: soil, nutrient, percentage, nitrogen

Long definition: Phosphate is the natural occurrence of the element phosphorus. Phosphorus-based compounds are solid at atmospheric temperatures and not available for atmosphere cycling. Because of this limitation in its cycle there is a tendency of P reduction in most non-treated soils as a result of slow run-off. P is important to photosynthesis as it is necessary for electron transport and ATP regeneration in the oxidative phosphorylation (Atwell et al., 1999). Leaf P, roots P and soil P are broadly correlated (Schreeg et al., 2014).
Label: soil, nutrient, phosphate

Long definition: THETA is the curvature of a non-rectangular hyperbola response of photosynthesis to light and it can be measured and described by equations but hardly predicted. It is a function of photosynthetic rate, absorbed irradiance, maximum quantum yield and photosynthetic maximum capacity (Égren and Evans, 1993).
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Leaf photosynthetic processes are highly dependent on temperature. Temperature dependence is widely incorporated into vegetation_climate models, and its effects on leaf carbon budget are a major constraint on plant productivity. Plants tend to acclimate to temperature regulating their photosynthetic thermal optimum to the prevailing thermal regime (Lin et al., 2013).
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long name: Maximum rate of carboxylation per leaf area at an ambient temperature of 25 degrees Celsius.
Long definition: Maximum rate photosynthesis is determined by the slower of two biochemical rates: the carboxylation of RuBP, determined by Rubisco activity (Vcmax); and electron transport for RuBP regeneration in the Calvin cycle (Jmax). When light is saturating, the amount of activated Rubisco determines the maximum velocity of carboxylation, Vcmax (Farquhar et al., 1980).Vcmax estimated in ambient temperature is standardized to 25 degrees Celsius applying an adapted Arrenius equation (Bernacchi et al., 2009). This standardization reduces biases due to temperature effects. Vcmax in an area based is calculated from photosynthesis in an area base. Area based traits reflect surface fluxes such as light harvesting and transactions through surfaces such as carbon assimilation and water transpiration (Wright et al., 2004).
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long name: Maximum rate of PEP regeneration per leaf area at an ambient temperature of 25 degrees Celsius.
Long definition: PEP carboxylase is the enzyme that fixes carbon in the compound oxaloacetate for C3 and CAM plants. PEP carboxylase efficiency is estimated by the initial slope of the response of photosynthesis to partial intercellular CO2 concentration (Von Caemmerer, 2000). The maximum rate photosynthesis is determined by the slower of two biochemical rates: the carboxylation of RuBP, determined by Rubisco activity (Vcmax); and electron transport for RuBP regeneration in the Calvin cycle (Jmax). When light is saturating, the maximum rate of photosynthesis will be determined by the carboxylation of RuBP (Farquhar et al., 1980). Photosynthesis determined in ambient temperature is standardized to 25 degrees Celsius applying an adapted Arrenius equation (Bernacchi et al., 2009). This standardization reduces biases due to temperature effects. Photosynthesis measured by IRGAs (Infrared Gas Analyzer system) is obtained in an area base. Photosynthesis in a mass base can be normalized to area base by simply dividing AMASS to leaf mass area (LMAQQ). Area based traits reflect surface fluxes such as light harvesting and transactions through surfaces such as carbon assimilation and water transpiration (Wright et al., 2004).
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Wood density is the dry mass of a section of a plantÍs stem divided by the dry wood volume of the same section. In broad terms, wood density is related to structural strength, plant life spam, plant height, trades-off with growth rate and stem defences against pathogens, herbivores and physical damage. In combination with plant size traits is important aboveground carbon storage (Cornelissen et al., 2003).
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Wood density is the fresh mass of a section of a plantÍs stem divided by the fresh volume of the same section. In broad terms, wood density is related to structural strength, plant life spam, plant height, trades-off with growth rate and stem defences against pathogens, herbivores and physical damage. In combination with plant size traits is important aboveground carbon storage (Cornelissen et al., 2003).
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable.  Carbon Dioxide Concentration used as reference to define the sample CO2. Measurements of photosynthesis are based on the differences in CO2 in an air stream that is flowing through the leaf cuvette
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable.  Carbon Dioxide Concentration measured inside the IRGA chamber. Measurements of photosynthesis are based on the differences in CO2 in an air stream that is flowing through the leaf cuvette
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: sample_CO2 minus reference_CO2
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable.  Water Concentration in air used as reference to define the sample H20. Measurements of transpiration are based on the differences in H2O in an air stream that is flowing through the leaf cuvette
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable.  Water Concentration in air measured inside the IRGA chamber. Measurements of transpiration are based on the differences in H2O in an air stream that is flowing through the leaf cuvette
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: sample_H2O minus reference_H2O
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable, relates to flow rate. The LI-6400 is an open system, which means that measurements of photosynthesis and transpiration are based on the differences in reference_CO2 and sample_CO2; and reference_H2O and sample_H2O in an air stream that is flowing through the leaf cuvette
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable. Temperature of the metal block containing the optical path of the IRGA is measured with a linearized thermistor.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable. Air temperature is computed from the signal of a linearized thermistor located just beneath the circulation fan in the sample IRGA.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable. Leaf temperature is measured with a chromel-constantan thermocouple junction. The reference junction is the IRGA block, whose temperature is known.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable. Atmospheric pressure is measured with a transducer located in the console of the LI-6400.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable. The in-chamber PAR sensor is a GaAsP sensor located in the top of the standard chamber.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable. The optional external quantum sensor is a LI-COR LI-190 Quantum Sensor.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Relative humidity is the ratio of vapour pressure to saturation vapour pressure; used as reference to define the sample RH
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Relative humidity is the ratio of vapour pressure to saturation vapour pressure.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Dewpoint temperature, the temperature at which condensation will occur, in the reference cell
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Dewpoint temperature, the temperature at which condensation will occur, in the sample cell
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. One-sided boundary layer conductance to water vapour is computed from a function of leaf area, the slope and offset of boundary layer to water vapour.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. One-sided boundary layer conductance to water vapour is computed from a function of leaf area, the slope and offset of boundary layer to water vapour.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Time of day is shown as an 8 character string containing HH:MM:SS on a 24 hour basis.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Area occupied by the leaf in the chamber. Maximum = 6 cm2
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: The number of observations that have been stored since the log file was last opened.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Time since logging started
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: LICOR system version
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable. Part of CO2 band broadening correction.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: The system constant Ebal? controls whether or not an energy balance computation is done.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Total boundary layer conductance for the leaf (includes stomatal ratio)
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Estimate of the ratio of stomatal conductance of one side of the leaf to the other
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Photosynthetic rate. The mass balance of CO2 in an open system. The equation is essentially derived from von Caemmerer and Farquhar 1981.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Conductance to H20. The stomatal conductance to water vapour is obtained from the total conductance by removing the contribution from the boundary layer. The equation is essentially derived from von Caemmerer and Farquhar 1981.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Intercellular CO2 concentration. The equation is essentially derived from von Caemmerer and Farquhar 1981.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Transpiration rate. The mass balance of water vapour in an open system. The equation is essentially derived from von Caemmerer and Farquhar 1981.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Vapour pressure deficit based on Leaf temperature. This is the difference in vapour pressure between leaf and what is actually in the air.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Vapour pressure deficit based on chamber air temperature. This is the difference in vapour pressure between chamber air and what is actually in the air.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed leaf temp. Same as Tleaf unless doing energy balance.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable.  One sided BL cond.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable.  Sample CO2 offset.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable.  Sample H2O offset.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable.  Reference CO2 offset.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable.  Reference H2O offset.

Long definition: Numerical value for Stable (stability). Shows the fraction of he number of stable variables (CO2S, H2OS, Flow) (e.g. Stable 1/3; 2/3; 3/3).

Long definition: Constant. Fraction of PARi to use for EB (energy balance).
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Constant. Fraction of PARo to use for EB (energy balance)
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Constant. Radiation conversion factors times absorption coefficients. Used in the conversion of _mol mol-1 to W m-2. Used for EB (energy balance).
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: This is a six digit numerical composite of the status flags. ñCHPWMFî is respectively: CO2 IRGAs; H2O IRGAs; Pump; Flow Control; CO2 Mixer; Chamber Fan. Number (1) means OK, number (0) means OFF, other numbers have variable meanings.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Ratio of Flow per area with units conversion
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Transpiration rate. The mass balance of water vapour in an open system. The equation is essentially derived from von Caemmerer and Farquhar 1981.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable. Leaf temperature is measured with a chromel-constantan thermocouple junction. The reference junction is the IRGA block, whose temperature is known.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Measured variable. Air temperature is computed from the signal of a linearized thermistor located just beneath the circulation fan in the sample IRGA.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Incoming radiation. PARi corrected by f_parin summed to PARo corrected by f_parout times alphaK.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Energy balance delta t. Delta t is used in EB (energy balance) and computes the leaf-air temperature difference.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed leaf temp. Same as Tleaf unless doing energy balance.
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Saturation Vapour Pressure of leaf temperature (Tleaf)
Label: label = key words for meta (Diver) search funtion e.g. leaf area, photosynthesis, maximum, CO2, Nitrogen

Long definition: Computed variable. Intercellular H2O concentration.

Long definition: Computed variable. Difference between Interecellular H2O and sample H2O.

Long definition: Computed chamber air temp. Same as Tair unless doing energy balance.

Long definition: Computed variable. Saturation Vapour Pressure of air temperature in the chamber (Tair)

Long definition: Computed variable. Conductance to H20. The total conductance to water vapour is obtained from the stomatal conductance and from the contribution of the boundary layer.

Long definition: Computed variable. Ratio of partial intercellular to ambient CO2 concentration.
